block.p: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC: PRESIDENT SWORN IN -- Hipolito Mejia was sworn in as president, promising to spread the benefits of an economic boom to the poor. The fight against corruption and poverty will be priorities for his center-left Dominican Revolutionary Party government, he said in his speech. Mr. Mejia won the May 16 election on a tide of discontent among voters who felt the nation's economic upturn had sidelined the poor.

ARGENTINA: DEVALUATION REJECTED -- President Fernando de la Rua told reporters he had no intention of devaluing the Argentine peso or replacing the currency with the United States dollar as suggested by former President Carlos Saul Menem. He criticized his predecessor for warning that Argentina was on the brink of a devaluation or depression.

CHILE: NEW RESTRAINTS ON PINOCHET -- Gen. Augusto Pinochet was stripped of his right to vote or enter the Senate after Parliament was officially notified that the Supreme Court had removed the former dictator's immunity as a senator for life to face possible charges of human rights abuses. Conservative senators promised to open a debate on the causes of 1973 coup that brought the general to power to show that Marxists were seeking to start a revolution.

COLOMBIA: INQUIRY INTO KILLINGS -- President Andres Pastrana ordered an investigation into allegations that army troops armed with assault rifles and grenades ambushed a school group and killed six students.

CANADA: FISHING CONFLICT -- A government fisheries boat rammed a boat manned by Quebec Indians who were backing New Brunswick Indians in a dispute over native fishing rights. The Indian boat was wheeling around the federal boat, trying to keep fisheries agents from pulling up lobster pots set by the Mi'kmaq natives of Miramichi, New Brunswick.

PHILIPPINES: HOSTAGE FREED -- Muslim rebels freed a Philippine woman they had kidnapped nearly four months ago. Government officials said they expected that more hostages, mostly foreigners, would be released soon under a deal bankrolled by Libya.

PAKISTAN: OUSTED LEADER'S APPEAL -- A lawyer for the deposed prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, told an appeals court that his client had a right to divert a commercial flight carrying Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the army chief he had just fired, because he feared the general's arrival would destabilize the country. Mr. Sharif was convicted of hijacking for diverting the flight and was sentenced to two concurrent life terms.

KASHMIR: ANTI-INDIA VIOLENCE -- Eight people were killed and 18 injured in violence in the state of Jammu and Kashmir in incidents involving anti-India militants, the police said. In one, a grenade tossed at Indian security troops missed and landed in a crowded market in Bijbehara, south of the summer capital of Srinagar.

CHINA: CULTURAL AGENCY IN TIBET BANNED -- Chinese authorities expelled the directors of the Tibet Heritage Fund, an international agency working in the Tibetan capital, Lhasa, and ordered the group to halt its activities. The order came as a surprise to the German-based group, which has been cooperating with Lhasa's Cultural Relics Bureau since 1997 to restore monasteries and traditional Tibetan houses dating back as far as the seventh century.

IVORY COAST: GENERAL FOR PRESIDENT -- Ivory Coast's military leader will run as an independent candidate in the Sept. 17 presidential elections, his aides said. Gen. Robert Guei, who came to power after a coup last year, will take part in the vote as a candidate ''above all parties,'' they said. The United States and France, the former colonial power, have discouraged him from running.

MOZAMBIQUE: GOVERNMENT CRITICS HELD -- The police have detained five opposition party members in the port town of Beira, saying they were planning to incite a nationwide campaign of civil disobedience, the state news agency reported. Officials in the opposition party, known as Renamo, denied such a plot. But Renamo officials said party members were angry after President Joaquim Chissano declined to appoint any Renamo officials to provincial governorships last month.

IRAN: HELICOPTER RESCUE -- An American ship rescued two crew members from an Iranian helicopter that crashed near an oil rig in the Persian Gulf, state-run radio reported. Iran does not have relations with the United States, which conservative elements of the Iranian government regard with great suspicion.

IRAQ: KUWAIT, TURKEY CRITICIZED -- Iraq criticized Turkey and Kuwait for assisting American and British air patrols, and said its ground-to-air missiles had again driven the planes back. American and British warplanes patrol air-exclusion zones over northern and southern Iraq and take off from bases in Turkey, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. Baghdad does not recognize the no-fly zones.

YUGOSLAVIA: OPPOSITION COMPLAINT -- Vojislav Kostunica, chosen by 15 Serbian opposition parties to challenge President Slobodan Milosevic in the election next month, criticized a United States move to open an office in Budapest to help the democratic opposition in Serbia, calling it interference in Yugoslavia's internal affairs. The State Department had said it was opening an Office of Yugoslav Affairs in the American Embassy in Hungary to ''support the full range of democratic forces in Serbia.''
